That this House condemn the government for its refusal to take action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment in Canada.
He said: Madam Speaker, this ought to be a happy day for Canadians. It is Valentine's Day. For millions of Canadians this day is like every other day has been over the last number of months and years.
Canada is facing its worst economic crisis since the thirties. There are 1.5 million Canadians unemployed and 2.2 million Canadians on welfare. While Canadians are suffering the anguish, the hardship, this government has taken a do-nothing, cross your fingers approach to dealing with the serious economic crisis that is facing Canadians.
At a time when Canadians are suffering this government has other priorities. Here we are on Valentine's Day, it is a Friday, debating the number one issue of concern to Canadians. This House has been back now for two weeks, and yet this House has not given priority to the issue of unemployment in the Canadian economy.
This House ought to be sitting today, tomorrow, Sunday, and every day and every evening to come up with ways to devise methods to put Canada back to work.
The Liberal Party put forward its plan for economic recovery, a modest plan. We recognize that there is a need to kick-start the economy, to put people back to work, to start creating jobs. So we presented a plan. Yet the government has refused to combat the high level of unemployment in Canada. The government has taken a do-nothing approach.
I am pleased to see the minister of employment in the House today. I look forward to hearing his remarks.
The biggest problem in Canada today is the Conservative government in Ottawa and the Bob White government at Queen's Park. Together these two governments-the NDP government at Queen's Park and the Conservative government in Ottawa-have destroyed the Canadian economy. They have shattered confidence. Time and time again Bob Rae and our Prime Minister say: "Well, it is a question of confidence; Canadians don't have confidence". Is it any wonder that Canadians do not have confidence when they have the likes of our Prime Minister and a labour led government at Queen's Park? The government at Queen's Park has totally turned off business and has created a climate or an atmosphere where business is afraid to expand, where business is afraid to invest in order to create the much needed jobs.
Is it any wonder that Canadians lack confidence in the future? That is a sad story.
The unemployment statistics were released last week. The rate was up again, 10.4 per cent. What does that mean in human terms? All too often we talk about percentages and we talk about rates. But let us try to think for a moment what that actually means to average people.
In the province of Ontario where I come from 504,000 people are unemployed; 504,000 people have to wait for their UI cheques in order to make their rental payments or make their mortgage payments. In the province of

It is a shame that the minister of employment has not done anything to help his own constituents in the province of New Brunswick.
A total of 1,429,000 Canadians are unemployed, out of work. Here we sat in the House of Commons with recession-proof jobs over the last number of years. Elected people, senators and public officials have not really had to worry about where the next paycheque was coming from.
I really wonder whether the minister of employment understands what it feels like not to know where the next cheque is coming from, whether he understands the uncertainty even in the minds of Canadians who are working in terms of whether there will be a job for them. Perhaps the minister can contemplate the thousands of Canadians today who instead of bringing flowers to their spouses, instead of bringing flowers home, will be bringing pink slips home, lay-off notices, termination notices. Can the minister of employment try to understand what it means to be unemployed and without work?
Canadians want to work. Those who are unemployed and those who are on welfare want the opportunity to be able to earn a living and to help other Canadians. Yet this minister and his government are doing absolutely nothing in order to kick-start the economy.
Perhaps the minister of employment and his government have yet to grasp the magnitude of the problem. They seem to be preoccupied with the Constitution. Yes, it is an important issue, but it is not the most important issue in the minds of Canadians. The most important issue in the economy is jobs.
I do not think that the minister of employment from New Brunswick understands the magnitude of the problem. I am sure his staff has briefed him on the violence that is erupting at employment centres across the country. It is that desperate.
Yesterday in Montreal violence erupted on the welfare lines. Yet this minister sits back and tells the House that he has a way of getting people back to work. He is going to train people. He is going to ensure there is long-term
prosperity. Little comfort that is to the millions of people who are either unemployed or on welfare.
The minister has stated time and time again that his government is committed to retraining. He said so in this House on a great number of occasions. The Prime Minister has said that his government is committed to retraining. We know that it not quite accurate.
An internal memo was released a few days ago. It was sent from directors general directly responsible to the minister of employment to all area managers across the country in Employment Canada, asking them to prepare contingency plans for three scenarios. The first was a 20 per cent reduction of regular funds for training. The second was a 35 per cent reduction of regular funds. The third was a 50 per cent reduction of regular funds. In effect it was slashing community based training right across the country.
A number of organizations in the riding of York South-Weston rely on this type of funding and will not be able to survive with these cuts.
What is at issue is the credibility of the minister. I know he prides himself on having some integrity. He stands and says that the government is committed to training and retraining. He says that in public, yet when he gets back to his comfortable office with his big desk, his comfortable chairs and his comfortable couch, with his recession-proof job, he tells his managers and directors to send out the word: "We are going to cut because I am responding to directions from my boss, the Prime Minister".
Shame on the minister of unemployment. He is not the minister of employment. He is the minister of unemployment. That is his responsibility. He has to assume and his government has to assume the responsibility. Because of its economic policies this country is facing the worst economic crisis since the thirties. Its high interest rate-high dollar policy has destroyed the manufacturing base in Ontario. It has destroyed hundreds of thousand of permanent jobs.
The memo goes out; they are cutting $100 million. The area manager in Toronto where I come from, Mr. Ron Crockford, says in a memorandum of January 10, 1992: "We will be forced to terminate projects due to budgetary reductions as opposed to performance related reasons if we reduce further".
That is the situation. Who are the people who will suffer? Will it be his friends in high places, his buddies on Bay Street, the guys he sips cocktails with? No. These
February 14, 1992

cuts will affect those people most in need of training: immigrants, women, youth, disabled people, older workers, linguistic and racial minorities. These are the very sectors which have been designated equity groups by the recently formed Canadian Labour Force Development Board. These are the people who need the government's help, and the government is turning its back. That minister is turning his back on the people most in need, and a lot of those people are in his own province. He is turning his back on his own people.
I look forward to the minister standing in this House to tell his constituents and other Canadians what he intends to do to alleviate the suffering. I would like to know what advice the minister gives. Presumably he finds time to revisit his riding on occasion, to listen to the unemployed fishermen, to listen to the unemployed people in his riding. What does he say to people when they come into his office and say: "Mr. Valcourt, I am unemployed. I am desperate. I need money. I need work. I have to pay the rent. I have to make the mortgage payment. I have to buy food for my children''. What does the minister say to those people? What does he say? What advice does he give to those people who are desperate for help from this government?
What he says to them is: "Deficit reduction is important. We have to reduce the deficit. We have to control the debt". This government has had eight years to deal with the national debt, and what has it done? It has doubled the national debt. It has had eight years to deal with the deficit, and what has it done? It has increased the deficit. It has implemented the goods and services tax that has made the situation even worse.
There is one way to bring back confidence in Canada and that is for this government to resign. It has lost the moral authority to govern. It has no support. It has the legal right, yes. The Prime Minister will hang on by his fingernails; he will hang on to power to the last bitter moment. He has the legal authority to carry on, but he has absolutely no moral authority. There is no support for this government. It is at 12 per cent or 13 per cent in public opinion. Canadians want the opportunity.

If the minister of unemployment is so sure of his economic plan, if he is so sure that he has the answer, if he is so confident that he will put people back to work, let him have the guts. Let the Prime Minister have the guts to issue the writ and let us go to the people of Canada. Let us present our platform and let us see who the people of Canada will put their trust in.
They will put their trust in the Liberal Party, in Jean Chretien and the Liberal Party, because they know our party has stood and will continually stand for the disadvantaged in our society. They know we will not allow the suffering that is taking place today. If the minister wants to instil a bit of confidence, let him have the courage to call an election.
Maybe that is what the Prime Minister is thinking. He is on his farewell tour. As a matter of fact, the T-shirts are at the printers. A number of communities will be listed on the back of these T-shirts. It is the Brian Mulroney farewell tour.

In closing, let me say that the Liberal Party has as its policy a full employment strategy. As the Official Opposition, the government in waiting, we will not rest until every Canadian who wants to work has the opportunity to work.
Our strategy is full employment. The strategy of minister of unemployment is full unemployment. Throughout the day today, Liberal members will be criticizing the government and explaining the Liberal Party economic recovery program to put this country back to work.

Madam Speaker, I want to pick up on a constructive idea that my colleague put forward in the opening part of his remarks.
He put forward an idea which I think most Canadians would like to see implemented. His idea was a challenge to the government, as I understood it, to create a situation in this House where rather than have the short, six-hour debate on probably the most important issue concerning the country today, namely putting people back to work, we debate this issue right through the weekend.
I ask my colleague, he being an experienced member of this House being here for many years, how he would orchestrate that or how he could engineer it with the minister. Could he elaborate a little bit on that? I think it is a worth-while idea that Canadians would like to see implemented.

Mr. Speaker, I believe with all the certainty that I can command, the people of Canada want parliamentarians to show some leadership.
They want to see parliamentarians and government understand what is relevant out there, what is happening at the grass roots level, what is happening at the street level. This is not the real world in this Chamber. This is not the Ritz.
It is a nice building, and we are very comfortable in it but we are too far removed from reality, especially when the government has decided, for example, that we should have, over the course of a number of evenings, special sittings of the House to debate the constitutional question. It is a very important question, the future of Canada, but people across the country do not think it ought to be the priority. Yet the government decided to set aside special time.
We are mired in a recession, yet no special time has been set aside by this government to deal with the question of unemployment. It was left up to us, the Liberal opposition, to take the first opportunity. We were allotted this day as an Opposition Day and we set the agenda according to what we believed to be the most important issue facing Canadians.
If the minister is ready, my colleagues and I are prepared to sit here all weekend long to talk about ideas, to talk about a recovery plan. We are prepared to debate, for example, the elements of the Liberal Party one-year emergency plan, whether it is the use of RRSPs to finance first- time homes, whether it is to debate the infrastructure program to accelerate capital projects in municipalities right across the country not only to improve the infrastructure but in order to create jobs. We are prepared to talk about training. We are prepared to talk about why Canada is still one of the lowest per capita investors in training among OECD countries.
I would like to hear from the minister when he has the opportunity. If he is really concerned about unemployment in Canada, I ask him to take me up on my challenge to him, the Liberal Party challenge, to sit here all weekend long to debate unemployment and the economy.

Madam Speaker, I just want to ask the hon. member for York South-Weston how he squares the fact that when he makes the statement that it is the Liberal Party that is in favour of full employment and the Progressive Conservatives who are in favour of unemployment with the reality that during those years leading up to 1984 the average job creation was short term, temporary and 80 per cent of all jobs created by the Liberals were short-term jobs and

more than 80 per cent of all job creation under the present administration are permanent, full-time jobs. How does he square statistical fact with his assertion that the Liberals believe in full employment when all they created were part-time jobs?

This is the kind of nonsense that we hear from Conservative members. They reach back to 1984 or to 1948 or to 1867. We are talking about today's reality.
Yes, governments past have made mistakes. I was not part of that government. I was a member of the party, but I was not part of the government. I am not taking John Diefenbaker to task for things that he did 20 or 30 years ago. We have a problem today. People are unemployed. They want to work. They want to get off the unemployment rolls. They are tired of relying on pogey.
Does the member know what pogey means? Does he know what it means to be unemployed? He is one of the members from Alberta. I have not seen him stand up in this House and go to bat for the disadvantaged in Alberta. Is it any wonder that the Tories in Alberta will be wiped out? Perhaps the member does not care any more because he knows he will not be returned to this House.
We are talking about today. This government has had eight years to get the country in order. What it has done is totally destroy it. It has dismantled it. We had three, four or five years of good solid growth in this country. What did it do? It frittered the opportunity away and has decimated a lot of good, well paying jobs in the country.
It behoves the hon. member from Alberta to stand up and reach back to the past to talk about job creation. A job is a job. People want to work. That is what they want to do. They want to put Canada back to work and that member is doing absolutely nothing to further that strategy of full employment.
I have not seen the minister of employment stand up and say: "It is the goal of this government to put every Canadian back to work". I have never, ever seen that member stand up and say that that is the policy of the Government of Canada.

speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to start by saying that I am very tempted to respond to the comments made by the hon. member for York South-Weston in his speech.

I thought we were here this morning to listen to the Liberal Party of Canada and its members in this House telling us how deplorable the employment situation is in Canada, and then they would tell us their solutions and offer us ways to solve the problem.
That member of the Liberal Party spoke for 20 minutes and, I say with all due respect to my learned friend, I listened attentively for 20 minutes. His colleague said the one good constructive idea he heard was that we should sit all weekend and talk about it. This government will not only talk about it, it will keep on acting on solving it.
I have listened to the doom and gloom scenario of the hon. member. I think we have to put our current economic woes in perspective. I know it is of little comfort to Pitou Dumont or Maurice Cote in my own riding who may be looking for better economic opportunities. It is of little comfort to any unemployed Canadian or social welfare recipient to know that economies around the world are in the midst of difficulties, but I think they have to know about it.
Economies around the world are in the midst of transition under the pressures of economic globalization, recession, inflation and political restructuring. A full one-third of the OECD countries are faced with unemployment rates of 10 per cent or more. We are reminded by the OECD that there are, among its member countries, 28 million jobless people.
Yes, our unemployment rate is 10.4 per cent and, yes, we have over one million Canadians out of work, but recovery, although sluggish, is under way both here at home and in the United States. The OECD knows better than the Liberal Party and it predicts that our employment growth rate will be 1.2 per cent in 1992.
What does that 1.2 per cent mean to the Canadians listening to this? It is 150,000 new jobs this year. That is a rate twice as high as the OECD average of 0.6 per cent.
Even the United States is expecting only to see unemployment grow by 1 per cent.
Further, our growth in GDP is estimated to be the highest of all the OECD countries in both 1992 and 1993. Our economic situation is difficult, but our international standing as a country is a testament to the sound economic management of this government.
Why is it that for all these other industrialized countries in the world that have these problems Canada, though not to our liking and doing as well as we hoped we would, is to do better than all of these other countries in 1992 and 1993.
To the average, reasonable Canadian, not the partisan yappers and not the people who do not care, the people who are only interested in rising and stirring up the crowd, the kind of speech we heard here a few minutes ago does not even reasonably look at what the problem is.
They talk about their solutions. How can you stand up and ask the taxpayers all across Canada to pay more taxes? How can you ask Canadians from coast to coast to sustain more taxes? That is what they are calling for. If they are not calling for more taxes then they are calling on the government to increase the deficit. They are saying: "Government, go and mortgage further the future of the children, of your children. Do like the Liberals did, borrow and do not worry whether you can pay it back".
The hon. member was talking about my people back home in my riding of Madawaska.

He asked me whom I was trying to fool. I am not trying to fool anyone, but I think the hon. member should have considered the following problem. Out of every tax dollar our farm producers and potato growers send to Ottawa, 36 cents is spent on interest charges. I cannot use those 36 cents to provide certain services. I cannot use them to help people who need help. I have to pay the interest on a debt.

Madam Speaker, I wish that all Canadians could see the spectacle of the rat pack back at it.
I was talking about the requirements to ensure that Canadians can get jobs. One of the factors is to improve the efficiency of the labour market.
The first factor in improving our competitiveness is in improving the efficiency of our labour market through skills upgrading. On the other side of the House the other political parties recommend short-term, make-work solutions, but make-work projects are band-aid solutions.
As I said earlier, it may have been the favourite approach during the seventies to remedy what were cyclical labour market difficulties, but the evidence today to anyone who really cares about the problem and tries to explain why and understand why is overwhelming that in the face of major structural changes to the economy more than band-aid solutions are required to respond to the labour market needs of the 1990s.
The Canadian economy of today has increased skill requirements and the nature and type of work has changed. If we are to be internationally competitive, we must respond appropriately to these changes through training. Make work is not the solution. We have structural problems, not cyclical problems.
Yesterday Speaker, I was meeting with the council of automotive and repair people and one garage owner here in Ottawa was telling me that he had put ads in the paper trying to get a qualified mechanic for his garage here in Ottawa and he could not find anyone qualified.
There is a shortage in Canada of skilled workers. Unemployed people have to tap these opportunities of training and retraining in order to get better qualifications in order to get into the jobs. In the long run training has benefits for both individuals and the country. We should consider that by the year 2000, and that is not far away, almost two-thirds of all new jobs will require at
least one year of educational training beyond high school.
Back in the 1970s it was easy to get a job with just a grade 9 education, but that is no longer the reality today. That is not the case any more. Training is also good from a macro-economic perspective, because a highly skilled work force attracts foreign investment in Canada.
Training raises productivity. Workers with higher skills are employed in higher productivity jobs, earning higher wages and making Canada more competitive. For that reason the government's priority has been the development of a skilled work force to accommodate economic and social change. For the unemployed there is no better time to train than during forced periods of unemployment.
When the economy recovers, human capital is improved and workers are prepared to take an active role in the labour force. However, more could be done with available resources to improve labour market efficiency by shifting priorities from passive income assistance and transfer to active measures, and from social treatment of unemployment to a more economic one.
In the OECD study of active versus passive program expenditures, Canada ranked 20th out of 23 member countries with only 24 per cent. Only 24 per cent of Canada's labour market program expenditures was spent on active measures. We began the transition toward more active policies with the labour force development strategy in 1989.
It became evident over the years that passive income generated significant disincentives to seeking employment. It certainly did nothing to develop the skills of the unemployed to make them more employable and more productive members of the labour force.
I see you indicating that I should conclude my remarks, Madam Speaker. The hon. member and his party vehemently opposed in this House and in the Senate the changes to the UI program we introduced two years ago. From 1990 to 1992 we have tripled the $600 million spent to train unemployed Canadians. This has gone up. In 1992 we will be spend $1.8 billion to train unemployed Canadians. I think that speaks louder than the yapping of the hon. member.

Nearly 50 per cent of Canadian teens are sexually active by grade 12. Each year 35,000 teenagers become pregnant, and 79 per cent of teen mothers are single. Sexual abuse is also prevalent among youth in Canada today. These shows are targeted to youth between the ages of 12 and 17.
I encourage all Canadian youth and their parents to watch these programs.

Madam Speaker, the Hickman Royal Commission was established by the federal and Newfoundland governments in February 1982 in response to the Ocean Ranger disaster.
This tragedy occurred on February 15, 1982 off the coast of Newfoundland and resulted in the loss of 84 lives.
The commission was charged with the responsibility to investigate the loss of the Ocean Ranger and all the members of its crew and to examine the safety of offshore drilling operations. Numerous recommendations have been acted upon.
Commissioner Alexander Hickman wrote two reports, one in 1984 and a second one in 1985. A total of 136 recommendations were developed relating to safety, training and government regulation of activity.
It should be noted that the majority of the recommendations have been addressed. The Hickman reports were released and the recommendations were addressed between the years 1985 and 1991.

speakeroldname: Mr. Albert Cooper (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
I am informed by the Solicitor General of Canada and the Department of Finance as follows:
The answer by the Solicitor General of Canada based on information maintained by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, much of which was provided by Revenue Canada, Customs, is:
1.	(a) The RCMP currently has 168 person-years dedicated to investigate Customs and Excise offenses within the country. In addition, all border detachments dedicate manpower to police the border in their areas and provide assistance to Revenue Canada, Customs as required.
(b)	The number of border crossing points between Canada and the continental United States depends upon the definition of border crossing points. There are many roads, lakes, rivers and fields that span the border and offer access to illegal smuggling operations.
(i)	According to information provided by Revenue Canada, Customs, they operate 118 ports of entry, of which 66 are manned less than 24 hours per day.
(ii)	Information from Revenue Canada, Customs indicates that 313 border crossings are unmanned. These consist of actual roadways crossings the border.
(c)	(i) As reported to the RCMP, Revnue Canada, Customs seized illegally smuggled tobacco at border points of value of $1,324,127.00 for the period 1 January, 1991 to 11 December, 1991.
(ii) The Departments of Finance, Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise and the RCMP agree that an estimated 10 to 15 million cartons of the projected 18 million cartons of Canadian cigarettes exported annually to the United States return illegally to Canada.
Routine Proceedings
2.	The government is aware of representations by certain groups that an export tax be imposed on cigarettes as a means of discouraging smuggling of these products. This is one of a range of possible approaches to address this problem.
The government is currently addressing this issue through several mechanisms. In 1989, a number of measures designed to deter the smuggling of tobacco products were introduced. These measures included improving the legislative provisions relating to the marking of tobacco packages to more clearly identify duty and tax paid products for exports. The penalties imposed under the Excise Act for selling tobacco products on which excise duty and tax have not been paid were also increased substantially at that time. More recently the Minister of National Revenue has been working with respective police authorities in an effort to develop better strategies to counter the problem of cigarette smuggling.

Madam Speaker, it is an unfortunate day for many people in this country.
It is particularly unfortunate for those in Atlantic Canada. We have seen today news of three major economic blows to Atlantic Canada.
We have seen first that the Hibernia project in Newfoundland, which was a project that certainly many people in Newfoundland thought was going to generate significant employment for themselves for the future, is frankly teetering on the very edge of collapse. There has been an announcement that lay-offs of 650 workers in Newfoundland, plus another 50 workers in Montreal will
take place. That is out of a total work force of about 1,100. We are talking about a massive proportion of the work force seeing their jobs disappear.
We have also seen that 1,100 people are being affected at Fisheries Products International. The lay-offs which have been announced there are supposedly temporary, for three months. There have been temporary lay-offs announced previously by FPI which have extended well beyond the original period that was set out.
In addition to that, we see that 810 jobs are being transferred by Sears Canada from Halifax to Ontario. You might think that as an Ontario member I would feel pleased about that transfer of 810 jobs to Ontario.
But I have to say I am a member of Parliament who believes in national unity in this country and in fairness to the economic development opportunities of our country. To see a transfer from a place like Atlantic Canada where there are very serious economic problems and where levels of unemployment are far higher than in the province of Ontario, to the province of Ontario does not make economic sense. It does not make social sense. It does not make sense in terms of building unity in Canada.
We have a very serious problem in Atlantic Canada which has come out today. We have a very serious problem in other parts of the economy. Today as well, MacMillan Bloedel in British Columbia announced 400 lay-offs in that province.
We see reports today in the press which indicate that the level of welfare recipients in the city of Montreal has reached a level where one person in seven in the city of Montreal is on social assistance and one-third of them are children.
We see in the province of Ontario and in the manufacturing sector generally across this country, figures that came out yesterday which demonstrate that whatever the minister has chosen to get up and say this morning, the manufacturing sector in this country is facing continuing inexorable decline in the face of the policies that this government has put into effect.
Last year there was a 6 per cent drop in manufacturing jobs in the manufacturing sector throughout this country concentrated in central Canada, but also in British Columbia, Manitoba and in parts of Atlantic Canada.
February 14, 1992

What we see across this country is a series of devastating declines.
The government gets up and says, as the minister said this morning, that the recovery is under way. This morning the minister talked about predictions from the OECD and how Canada next year is going to grow so much' better. We would have more faith in those kinds of predictions if we had not heard exactly the same thing from exactly the same ministers a year ago. They told us that recovery was under way, that we would be growing faster than any other part of the world.
What we have seen the past year is that the so-called recovery has meant an increase in unemployment, a decrease in output, a decline in the manufacturing sector and assaults on our resource sectors from Atlantic Canada to British Columbia.
There is no recovery here, no recovery whatsoever. [Translation]
It is very sad to see what is happening in Montreal today. In one of Canada's major cities, one person out of seven is on welfare and one-third are children. We also heard today that people are fighting in Montreal's welfare offices. How can the government remain unmoved by scenes of such utter despair? When will this government finally do something to stimulate the economy, create jobs and revive the hopes of people in Montreal and across Canada, people in small towns in Quebec and Ontario, people in western Canada and the Atlantic provinces?

The minister spoke this morning. What did he say? I have talked already concerning his comments about the recovery being under way and his suggestion that the people on this side of the House are just raising these questions for some kind of rhetorical effect.
New Democrats have had two significant cross-country tours in the past year to try to get directly from the people of this country how they are hurting. If some of us speak with heat, if some of us speak with passion, about what is taking place in the economy it is not because we want to play to TV cameras or to play to the House of Commons. It is because we have heard these people, met these people throughout Canada, and they have told us

how tough things are. We have heard them tell us how hope has been disappearing for their families. We heard people in Montreal, in Kitchener, in Guelph, in Windsor, in Saskatoon, in Vancouver, in Halifax, tell us about the increases in social welfare taking place, about what unemployment is doing to the fabric of their family life, to the fabric of community life within their societies.
Let me tell you, Madam Speaker, it hurts. We have to somehow get across to this government that people across the country are hurting. It is not a myth. It is not just something that shows up in the statistics. It is real live Canadians for whom the government has the responsibility of governing.
I am sorry it has the responsibility of governing them. I am sorry that it sits on the government's shoulders. Would that it sat on somebody else's shoulders, because it has not shown a sense of compassion and a sense of understanding the realities which so many people across this country are feeling.
We get up on our side of the House, and perhaps with some frustration, to speak about what we hear, what we see, what we know people are feeling across this country. The minister says: "You do not really care because you are being emotional". I am sorry, it is not possible for us to talk about the depth of the problem in this country without being emotional. It is not possible to talk about
1.5	million people being out of work, about one million on social welfare assistance across Canada without a deep sense of emotional hurt that this is happening in our country and a deep sense of anger that this government, which has been elected to take decisions, is not prepared to give the leadership that will show us some hope and direction for the future in this country.
The minister talked in his speech about: "The suggestion that you are making for recovery in this country, all that means is more taxes". If we get people back to work, if we stop having to pay for people on social assistance, if we stop having to pay the $30 billion that is now being spent on unemployment insurance, that saves money. It is keeping people alive. It is providing people with some kind of stop-gap measure in the face of deep economic problems. It is not giving us any kind of even medium term solution.
I have to say it is remarkable to hear this government talk about how terrible it is to raise taxes when this very government and the very minister who was speaking to the House brought into effect an increase in unemployment insurance premiums just six weeks ago here in Canada. It was a very significant increase of 7 per cent in unemployment insurance, brought in by this very minister who says: "It is the opposition which wants to increase taxes". It is not the opposition which wants to increase taxes; it is this government that has increased taxes. .
The minister talks about the causes of our great national debt. I wish that he would talk about the unanimous report of the finance committee of this House of Commons. It is a committee which has a Conservative majority. Liberal and New Democrat members are on the committee as well. That committee came up with a unanimous report saying that yes, the deficit is a problem and the government should tighten up in ways to see to it that we do not increase that deficit.
What was the government's response to that unanimous report? It rejected the three or four specific ways in which the finance committee unanimously suggested tightening things up. So much for the reality of this government's commitment to doing something about the deficit. It is a not a reality which really exists.
One of the recommendations, for instance, was that there should be no more possibility for tax giveaways without them being compensated for by reallocations in the rest of the budget. Did the government say: "Yes, that makes sense. If we give money away through taxes, we have to make sure the deficit does not go up by reallocating money from other parts of the budget"? Did it say yes to that sensible suggestion? No, it said no. It tells us that what it really cares about is scoring partisan points rather than trying to deal with the serious difficulties of unemployment, of debt and of deficit in this country.
There are four New Democrat governments in this country provincially and those four governments are
trying to deal seriously, with a sense of reality, with the problems of unemployment and of deficit. They have recognized that you cannot increase your deficit, that you cannot create a situation in which in a world economy, the world money market decides that you are a basket case. Therefore, the deficit must be dealt with in a responsible way.
It is tough, very tough. Hard choices have to be made but they are being made by New Democrat governments: tough choices to reallocate expenditure rather than increase deficits so as to see to it that we get jobs in this country so that we expand employment in this country, so that we give hope to people in this country. That is what we ask for from this government, a serious nonpartisan sense of caring for the hundreds of thousands of Canadians who are without work.
I am just sorry that the minister this morning has not demonstrated that sense of non-partisan compassion and sensible economic policy making which is so essential to solving our economic problems in the future.

Madam Speaker, I listened attentively to the member from the New Democratic Party. I take him at his word when he talks about New Democratic governments trying to take seriously the sense of reality out there and the sense of reality vis-a-vis the unemployment problems we have and the reality of the deficit.
I have a very simple request of this member. For two weeks in a row I have been presenting to members of the New Democratic Party a project in the province of Ontario north of Toronto that will employ close to 12,000 people in permanent jobs, a project that will create close to 5,000 affordable homes. It is the first ever green town development in north America using recycled materials, all being organized and reviewed by some of the most sophisticated environmental organizations. It is a project that meets all the various requirements of the farming community, agriculture, et cetera. It is not asking the province of Ontario for one nickel.

My simple question to the member is this: Will he take this proposal which has been delivered by many others, including myself, to the premier of Ontario, the Hon. Bob Rae, and will he use his forces as a member of the New Democratic Party to see if he can get some movement on this project? I as a member of the opposition have tried through fax, through phone, through letter, and have not been able to get a response for months. Will he do that for me?

Madam Speaker, I first have to say, of course, that I am not a member of cabinet of the provincial Government of Ontario. I certainly can give my assurance to my colleague that I would be very interested in looking at the proposal he talks about. Certainly, as he describes it, it sounds like something that deserves careful scrutiny and review.
Once I have had a chance to look at it and to talk with the member for Broadview-Greenwood about the proposal, I would be quite prepared to talk with the cabinet ministers responsible at Queen's Park and try to determine the issue.
I do want to make a brief comment, if I could. The member referred to the delays in the decision-making process in the Ontario government. For the Ontario New Democrat government which has been in power for about 18 months now, this has been a continuing and serious source of frustration.
On taking power as a party, we found ourselves faced with a mammoth bureaucracy which had been created over a long period of power. Frankly some people have blamed it on the Liberals. The Conservatives continually blame what took place in Ontario in the 1980s on the Liberal government of Premier David Peterson. In fact one should look much more carefully at the Conservative governments which were in power provincially for a much longer period of time and allowed this set of bureaucratic agencies and ministries to develop which have made it very difficult to get rapid approvals for projects to take place. However, what is taking place in Ontario is an attempt to try to sort these things out.
For instance, in the case of the ministry of municipal affairs, there is a very strong effort being put into place to try to see that different levels of government have clear levels of responsibility. It is called disentanglement.

Madam Speaker, I first of all want to compliment my colleague from York South-Weston for choosing this topic today.
Quite frankly most of us would agree in this House that the people in our ridings believe this is the number one issue facing this country today, namely getting people back to work.
February 14, 1992

I am going to try to take a little different tact in my remarks today.
I listened to the Minister of Employment and Immigration earlier today and I agree with his remarks that we are dealing with a restructuring of all the economies of the different countries in the world. He is absolutely correct. I do not debate that point with him.
I debate with him when he speaks of his commitment to retraining. I do not see it happening. I gave as a specific example the Woodgreen community centre in my riding. It is one of the most productive community centres in the whole city. Its track record in serving training needs throughout the community has been noted by many agencies as being superior. Yet, it is not only being frozen in terms of its resources to allow it to continue its service to the community but it is being cut back by 10 per cent.
There is a question of trust here. He even said in his answer: "Oh, well, I have to sort of look at these resource allocations again". I hope he will follow through and review the Woodgreen community centre because it is a very important contributor to the community.
So often we forget that when times are tough governance is supposed to be there for those who are most in need. Governance is not for those who do not need help. It is for those who are most disadvantaged and most in need.
It seems to me that the minister must review the Woodgreen request in that light.
The minister also made the point that we on this side of the House were not challenging him with new ideas or ways to advance this debate on putting people back to work. I really take exception to that point. I take exception because my colleague, the member for York-South Weston who initiated this debate on behalf of the Liberal Party of Canada, and our leader issued a challenge to the government. It is not a partisan challenge, let's face it. No party has a lock on how to put people back to work. All of us working together will get this job done, especially in light of the point the minister made that this is not a problem unique to Canada. This is a problem the whole world is facing.
Quite frankly I did not think that it was a good response to the idea of encouraging even further debate and exploring ideas.

There are lots of ideas out there and in here on how to put Canadians back to work. To begin with, I want to refer specifically to a document entitled Work For Tomorrow-Employment Opportunities for the 1980s. This was the result of a parliamentary task force in place during the early 1980s. This was a task force composed of all members of the House of Commons. This was a task force that worked for close to two years during the last major recession we had in this country. After listening to successful people from all over the country who were weathering that terrible recession which we as a government were involved with, we as Liberals-we do not run away from that-after listening to people from all over the world and after listening to ways to put people back to work, the task force came forward with this document with 186 different ideas.
I recommend this document not only to all parliamentarians in this House but to all parliamentarians in every legislature throughout this nation. It includes 186 ideas put together by members of Parliament from all sides of the House, ideas that came to them from people from coast to coast, in every sector of the economy and every region of the country. So often we try to reinvent the wheel in this place. It is not necessary. This document has some ideas that are as good today as they were then. So often we push paper and create work when some of the basic answers are right before us.
I challenge the minister of employment to review and reissue this document to all parliamentarians. This is what Canadians are bugged about. He is focused on ratcheting down inflation. Quite frankly, I would challenge the model right now that says there is any inflation in this country. I cannot see it. I do not know of it anywhere. My point is the deep economic pain that is out there for those people who are most in need.
We do not seem to have a life raft for them. At what point in time does the government say: "Our fiscal framework is on track. We are ahead of schedule. Now, let's look after those who are most disadvantaged in our society". At what point do you make that change?

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to respond to that. Let me come at it from two directions.
First, in Canada, 90 per cent of the population is working. What we are talking about with some of the policies is to get that 90 per cent feeling more confident to start to invest. That will help the unemployment side.
That is one side we are working on. On the other side, I think the member is absolutely correct. It appears that our inflation targets are going to be met and that we are somewhat ahead of ourselves. Interest rates are a little lower than we have targeted.
I do not know what will be in the budget. I have a lot of opportunity to input to the minister, but I do not know what will ultimately be in it. I have recommended to the minister that because of some of these things that the member has mentioned and because there is still a serious unemployment problem, we should look at easing some of the levers by some capital projects.
I must suggest that my view of capital projects is different from those that the provincial government has responsibility for. I believe that we have our jurisdiction where we can invest some money. I have made some recommendations to the minister not to support a huge increase in spending, but to look at some areas where we know we are going to have to make some capital investment because of the kind of things that the
member has mentioned. I have encouraged that there be a look at some of these projects.
Of course, the biggest one, and I believe it was mentioned during Question Period, is the fixed link to Prince Edward Island. I recommended that and a number of others. Not every project needs to cost $1 billion. There can be some really worth-while projects, spending $50,000 here and $100,000 there, and maybe even $1 million in other locations.
Through a variety of programs, but fundamental at least to my outlook, we can in fact achieve those targets that we have set out.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the hon. member very closely. I spent some time with him in Saint-Jean trying to learn some French. I got to know him quite well and I know he speaks very sincerely.
He said that the government does have an action plan. I listened to him very carefully. What is it? Is it predicting that there will be a recovery? Is that the government's action plan?
He talked about the fundamentals that it has laid down. Is that the government's action plan? He does know that there are 300,000 skilled jobs required in this country right now. There are 1.5 million unemployed. What is the government's action plan to match these demand jobs right now and the 1.5 million people who are looking for jobs?
In Question Period I asked the minister of employment if he would implement at least part of the Liberal five-point plan for economic recovery. He definitely said: "No, because it would not provide permanent jobs. It would provide all short-term jobs". Yet, the member is agreeing with us now that there are some public works projects that might create jobs and help the unemployed.
What is the government's action plan for matching the
300,000	skilled workers required right now with this huge population looking for jobs?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate that the Liberal action plan has five points in it.
One of the five which is a very public and very highly demanded plan is the down payment reduction on housing. That has been implemented by the government. To suggest that we are not looking at anything, one of
February 14, 1992

their own ideas that he supports has been implemented.
The relevant issue is that 300,000 jobs are going unfilled because they are for trained people. Certainly I have seen in my riding, and I am sure all members have seen that over the last year, the government has moved a considerable amount of money into the training budget. I am sorry I do not have the numbers in front of me exactly, but I believe it was increased over the last two years from just over $1 billion to just under $3 billion.
That is a substantial increase in funding in the training programs. I would suggest that hopefully all of those people involved in those training programs, or many of them, will look at those 300,000 jobs which are going unfilled and be qualified to fill them.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this debate today. Let me remind the House of the motion we are discussing:
That this House condemn the government for its refusal to take
action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment in
Canada.
Many Canadians could have written this motion, perhaps not as eloquently as the hon. member for York South-Weston because very few people have such eloquence, but most of them think exactly what is in this motion.
First, let me take this opportunity to congratulate the member for York South-Weston on his recent appointment as the employment critic for the national Liberal Party. I am sure that I speak on behalf of all members of this House in congratulating the member. We know that he will really hold this minister and this government to account for the shortcomings of the Conservative government.
This government has so many shortcomings that it would probably take 85 critics to keep it honest in that regard, if that is possible. However, I know that the member for York South-Weston will do a tremendous job not only for the national Liberal caucus but indeed for all Canadians who want us to air that grievance with the government in order to obtain redress.
When I said that several million Canadians feel exactly as the member for York South-Weston does, I was not
Supply
making a merely partisan remark. In addition to the feelings we have as parliamentarians there are very concrete statistics to support what we are saying.
I have before me an article written by Frances Russell, which appeared in the Winnipeg Free Press on February 5, 1992, and presumably in other Canadian newspapers as well. She points out that between June 1989 and October 1991, under the Conservative government, 461,000 manufacturing jobs were lost.
The hon. member for Edmonton Southeast referred to those very depressing statistics only a few moments ago. Yet, we hear some members across the way who say they are on the right track. What would things be like if this government were on the wrong track? We are losing this many jobs while the government pretends to be going in the appropriate direction.
The people of my riding do not think that what is happening now is at all satisfactory. The government pretends that this situation is world-wide.

Although the recession is not unique to Canada, Mr. Speaker, you are non-partisan and with your great objectivity and neutrality, you will understand that Canada's present situation has been made much worse by the monetary policy of the government opposite and also by the policy of too high interest rates. Of course our overvalued currency has cost Canada jobs that went abroad. This brought on the recession in Canada even before it was felt in other parts of the world.
We see that this government has greatly contributed to the recession. I would even say that the Canadian government beat others to the recession.
Before the nation-wide recession, created by the government opposite, many parts of our country were already suffering from recession. Take eastern Ontario, for example. In my riding of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, in Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke, in Stormont- Dundas and in others, we started to feel the effects of this recession long ago. That is why some of my colleagues and I asked the Conservative government opposite in 1990 to establish an economic recovery program for eastern Ontario. We were so disadvantaged in our

February 14, 1992
Supply
area that we needed such a program, even before the recession hit the rest of the country.
What we did not know then is that the worst was still to come.

I have before me a front page article from the Standard- Freeholder, a newspaper in Cornwall, Ontario, of Tuesday, August 28, 1991. It is entitled "Eastern Ontario Needs Job Help". It talks about the fact that an all-party committee of members of the Ontario legislature was on tour in eastern Ontario and it heard of the terrible economic conditions in eastern Ontario. It heard from the mayor of Cornwall, not from the member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, that companies needed incentive to relocate in the region.
I would like to quote then Mayor Phil Poirier: "Ontario's competitiveness as an economic region is being weakened by its reluctance to match its competitors' actions, and the same applies for the federal government which has failed to provide economic assistance to eastern Ontario the way preceding governments have done".

Now hon. members opposite like to say: "Well, you know, you Liberals have no alternative". They say that or they say: "You have alternatives but they cost too much". That again is wrong.

For those across the way who ask what is the alternative, our leader, the member for Beausejour, announced a few weeks ago a five-point program to improve the economy of this country.
Let me go through those points, and I will also discuss how we are going to pay for them. I invite the Conservative members to take note, to write it down or get someone else to write it for them so that they can adopt these policies.
(1)	We ask for a 5 per cent minimum down payment for first-time home buyers. That is cost neutral and the government has done it already. We thank it for making this first step. There are four more yet to be taken.
(2)	Permit the use of the registered retirement savings plans for first-time home buyers. This program has no cost to it. All you do is borrow from your own RRSP, put some sort of an attachment on the property, and if and when you ever sell the property you put it back into the RRSP. There is obviously no cost attached to that, not even the loss of potential income tax, nothing. There is no cost at all attached to this particular plan of our leader, the member for Beausejour.
(3)	A shared cost infrastructure program. Yes, we have called for this program. One billion dollars is the cost of it. How do we pay for that? First, in my own province of Ontario the provincial government has already agreed to contribute matching funds. It has already agreed to pay for half of it. In addition, we must remember that by not paying unemployment insurance much of that money would be coming back, some $350 million of it.
There are two more components. One is intensified basic skills training in Canada and the other is emergency funding for food banks which we would pay for by cancelling government polling and advertising.
We have offered alternatives.

I call on members opposite to listen to the grievances of the Canadian people, those in Glengarry-Prescott- Russell and elsewhere, who want an economic recovery program to get the economy going again and not platitudes from the government which likes to tell us that it is on the right track.
They are not on the right track. Eighty-four per cent of Canadians who have had it with the Prime Minister and his government know that they are not on the right track. The Prime Minister spoke the truth yesterday. He told Canadians who do not like his policies not to vote for him. That is exactly what they intend to do, and I hope that it will be soon.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Every Canadian.

Certainly, I say to my friend from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, if every Canadian could vote on this resolution there would be a thumping majority in favour, I will tell him that.
The unfortunate thing I say to him and to this House, is that this House no longer really represents the majority wishes of Canadians. It is true that at the time of the election in 1988 a majority of members of a particular party stripe were elected. But the sad commentary on that group is that they no longer reflect the wishes of the people who sent them here.
The best example of that is the goods and services tax, where fully 85 per cent of the people-and I have no reason to believe the proportions are any different in Tory ridings than in other ridings-have voiced their opinion very strongly against that tax. Yet these people sit here and allow the will of the people to be thwarted.
If the people of Canada could say today "we condemn the government for its refusal to take action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment", they would support almost unanimously that resolution. I say "almost unanimously". There would be exceptions to that. It would not be a unanimous vote.
There are some people out there who would disagree with this resolution in all fairness. And who are they? Well, they are the people who have jobs, thank you very much. They are the people who ran those big ads about free trade during the last federal election. They are the people who are benefiting from a massive tax break from this government. I am sure everyone knows the statistics.
Those who earn $100,000 or more a year in this country are now paying $1,600 less in federal taxes than when this government took office; $1,600 fewer dollars each year than was the case when this government took office in 1984. Those earning $30,000 or less a year are
now paying $1,200 more a year in federal taxes than in 1984.
What is the net message? That this government is looking after its own rich friends. Those rich friends, if they were to vote on this resolution, would find nothing wrong with what this government has done because this government has looked after them very well in tax terms and in every other way possible.
I was particularly interested in what the hon. member for Ontario had to say. I thought perhaps his remarks were maybe the most informative from that side of the House in that he got into announcing aspects of what is going to be in the budget. He may be in some trouble with his colleagues for that, but that is quite another story.
At least his candour can be complimented. I found what he had to say to be very informative as to what will be in the budget. It contradicts what he was saying earlier about the need for more restraint and the big bugaboo was the deficit. He spent much of his time on that, but when he let his hair down he talked about how this government has some plans to do some spending when the time is politically ripe. I am interested in hearing more from him on that issue.
Yes, today is Valentine's Day, February 14, a day when we turn our thoughts to particular subjects but, irony of ironies, it is also the day that this country is being pummelled as never before.
I am sure you have heard about the lay-offs of hundreds of people in the forestry industry in the Albemi Valley on Vancouver Island by MacMillan Bloe-del today. I am sure you have heard of the closing of a Sears catalogue office in Halifax today.
I particularly want to flag the two items that we have mentioned already today, one being the Hibernia situation with its drastic employment impact and the giving of notice to 1,000 workers, and the other being 850 plant workers and 155 trawlermen in relation to the Catalina, Newfoundland plant operated by Fisheries Products International.
Just those four locations that I mentioned: Port Alber-ni in British Columbia, Halifax in Nova Scotia, Catalina in Newfoundland, and of course Hibernia at Bull Arm and other sites in Newfoundland, bring into sharp focus once again the difficulties that are being faced by the
February 14, 1992

people of this country. People cannot even assume from one day to the next they have a job.
Some of the misery of today, and I am thinking particularly about Hibernia, has been inflicted because of a commercial decision. At least that is the immediate reason, but a good part of the misery being inflicted today can be traced directly to government policy.
Why is the forestry industry whether in British Columbia or in Newfoundland or elsewhere in trouble? It is because of the high dollar. You heard the double-talk from the hon. member for Ontario in succeeding mouthfuls. He talks about how he is pleased the dollar is coming down and how at the same time he supports everything the government does.
Well which is it? What this government has done is kept the dollar artificially high at the expense of thousands of jobs in the forestry industry, the mining industry, the fishing industry, indeed any industry in which we export the product. That is certainly the case for the three industries I have just mentioned, three industries that Newfoundland depends very heavily on: forestry, mining and fishing.
Take as a second example the loss today in Catalina, Newfoundland of 1,000 jobs. Why does FPI, the company concerned, find it necessary to give these notices? The answer is clear and it is in its press release. I believe it relates to quota reductions. What causes quota reductions? The massive foreign overfishing which this government almost invited in 1985 and has allowed to go on year after year ever since.
Only today, during Question Period, I was asking the Deputy Prime Minister if the time was not indeed right for this government to give notice to the offending nations that enough is enough and that we intend to unilaterally extend jurisdiction, marine maritime jurisdiction, to embrace the nose and tail of the Grand Banks.
The motion is all about the failure, the refusal of this government to take action.
Whenever you have different parties represented in a forum such as this, you will have different views about monetary policy, about any number of policies which will

have an impact on job generation. Irrespective of our differing ideologies, where there ought to be no difference is in the need to do some common sense things.
What could be more common sense than putting an end to this flagrant overfishing I have mentioned? What could be more common sense than allowing the dollar to come down a bit so that our exports are more competitive.
Yes, we condemn the failure of this government. Its failure has been so blatant, so stubborn and so arrogant. Does it not care at all? Doesn't anyone who sits on that side of the House care at all about the misery that has been inflicted, about the lives that are being destroyed, about the university education that will never go forward, about the families that are breaking up, about the increased crime?
These are all manifestations which flow directly from these very, very difficult economic times created in large measure by this administration.
Yes, we condemn that and that is why I am so delighted to support this resolution.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Trade
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this motion and this debate provide me with an opportunity as a former industrialist to think aloud, to share my views and even to speak my mind.
As legislators it is important that we take the time to meet and exchange ideas, to get to the heart of the major challenges facing the nation instead of merely skimming over them, to seek the cause of the problem instead of just focusing on the symptoms, to take a good hard look at some of the major forces which are now shaping our national and international agendas, forces that challenge each of us in our respective fields but which are necessary if we are to be efficient or even survive.
How much stronger our nation would be if such an opportunity for change came our way more regularly, in all regions of our country and in all walks of life. Yet, it seems that we have fewer opportunities for substantive
February 14, 1992

dialogue. What is really paradoxical is that at the same time the vagaries of our times call for even more discussion and debate. This creates a stronger need for public consensus as a basis for achieving our goals.
You are all well aware of the financial, constitutional, environmental, international and social issues which we all are currently interested in. I would like to share with you, Madam Speaker, and with the members of this House my own feeling on one or two truly fundamental issues, issues that have received little or no attention in our daily lives or in the media but yet set the tone to all the others.
Two closely related forces are sweeping the planet: the emergence of a global economy and the coming of the information age.
Whatever labels one uses, the fact is that the age we are now in is very different from the one that the two generations before us knew. The industrial age is over; the knowledge age is here. National borders are blurred as global systems dominated by world-wide corporations and three huge trading alliances emerge. A new world order is taking shape. The market economy is winning the whole world.
Those who refuse to admit it and remain attached to old ways are left behind. In politics and the huge government bureaucracy, pressures for change are enormous but change is slow in coming.
Instant access to information and universal education have dramatically increased the power of individuals. Now individuals want to have a say in decision making. That in itself is a force for change.
Greater individual involvement tremendously enriches our society and our democracy, but the political process, which includes both the government and private institutions, must be thoroughly rethought to reflect the new autonomy of individuals and the new interest groups which are more powerful than ever, not only to involve them in decision making, Madam Speaker, but also because today it is time to recognize that individual behaviour, translated into daily action, is a greater determinant of what the nation is than are government decrees.
Supply
Individuals express themselves on all the markets of the land; they cause things to happen. We must therefore take another look if we want the political process to work well. In doing so, we must also reform institutions and think of new mechanisms. We must manage more efficiently, privatize, and deal with those who cannot deal with the changes.
As a government, we must be more concerned with developing co-operation and consensus on a wide scale. We must encourage attitudes and behaviours in that direction. A new fundamental reality has appeared with the information age and the global economy and it has a direct effect on our society. This perception of the new reality has been one of the key points of the government's agenda since 1984. This agenda has been consistently pursued, although there have been some mistakes along the way, I agree. We have pursued this agenda despite massive constraints of all kinds, not the least of which is certainly the ideological heritage of Liberalism that has continued to haunt us, a heritage that continues to mislead too many Canadians.
After decades of watching a titanic government spend massively, a government guided by a vision of society and the public service that belongs to a bygone era, the federal government's strategy for economic renewal is in striking contrast. It clearly shows the coherent vision of a national economy that does not have to suffer government interference and where individual initiative and entrepreneurship take on their full importance.
By reducing the public debt, by slashing wasteful spending and inefficient programs, by reforming the tax system and extending trade opportunities, and by consolidating international markets, the prosperity initiative which the Minister for International Trade and the Minister of Employment and Immigration launched last October is another major step in this series of coherent initiatives.
Canada, as you know, faces a serious competitive threat. We are lagging behind our main international competitors, especially in terms of productivity and knowledge acquisition. We are proposing a serious attempt to inform Canadians about a whole complex of issues. We have created consultation procedures to take the public debate further and to encourage consensus.

First, it is innovative and that is somewhat risky. Second, we have involved the private sector in it. Third, a solid base has been established for developing a national action plan this year. This plan will include not only all governments but also all interest groups in Canadian society, and here I include all members of this House. This initiative is a perfect example of a government that understands the new realities of our time.
This process is bound to succeed if you, together with other leaders in Canadian society, recognize that you must take part, if you encourage all the other partners in our society to commit themselves fully, and if everyone together determines the process.
