I remember when I first came to this House in 1984 and when our Prime Minister talked about privatizing some Crown corporations, the first ones mentioned were Canadair in Montreal and de Havilland. Madam Speaker, you will recall that we had a very lively debate in this House because the opposition was absolutely opposed to the government's idea of selling Canadair and de Havilland to private interests.
However, we knew very well that if a successful Canadian and Quebec company of Bombardier's magnitude wanted to acquire Canadair, it would turn it into a profitable private venture, and we would no longer have to put up with the deficits that we had with Canadair and de Havilland. Indeed, in one year the federal government had to absorb a $1 billion deficit.
We are now in 1992, and who saved de Havilland in Toronto, Qntario? I admit that there are many lay-offs there right now. But it was Bombardier, a company from Quebec and Canada. Who saved UTDC in Toronto which belonged to the Government of Ontario and was later bought back by Lavalin? It was Bombardier, a company from Quebec and Canada. Who saved Canadair in Montreal? Again it was Bombardier, a company from Quebec and Canada.
Today we realize one thing: The three corporations that were privatized are now making profits and are creating jobs.
I thank the member for Levis who brought this issue to my attention. I am very proud of Bombardier and its input in Canada's economy.

Madam Speaker, two points came to mind as the hon. member for Kamouraska-Riviere-du-Loup was speaking. He comes from a resource area and I likewise come from the resource area of northern Ontario. We have had massive lay-offs in both the uranium mining industry in Elliot Lake where we have lost some 2,500 of 4,000 jobs in the last couple of years and we will be losing another 1,000 this year when Denison Mines shuts down.
February 14, 1992

One of the problems we are running into in regard to training, and I have spoken to the minister about this, is the problem with the training allowance under Bill C-22. There is provision for up to three years of training, but unfortunately it is a highly segmented, regimented system.
What we really need is more flexibility so that a person starting, whether it is at the late high school level or early high school or even in literacy training, would be able to start at whatever level their proficiency was at and then move through for four years of training on to skills training and technical training. That is the one point that came to my mind and I think it is urgent.
The second point is that the government really needs to take some immediate action now to stimulate the economy. The leader of my party proposed that we have an infrastructure program where a billion dollars would be set aside by the federal government which would be matched equally by the provinces and municipalities. That way we would get things moving out of this recession. I think that is important.
The other matter that needs to be looked at is co-operation between the federal and provincial governments. Mr. Bob Rae was on the television a few weeks ago and outlined what a disastrous situation the Ontario economy was in, but he did not give much prescription. The one thing that he did propose was that his government would be willing to match dollar for dollar any initiatives by the federal government.
I have proposed to the premier that the federal government has offered to provide up to $30 million for Elliot Lake to build a francophone community college in that community. I am challenging him to come forward with the provincial share of that funding so that that project can go forward.
It is hard to believe but the premier seems to be trying to establish some board of governors to put the decision at arm's length. Whereas he is the premier and his cabinet is responsible for education, they should make a decision and establish a community college for francophones in Elliot Lake. It has broad support throughout northern Ontario. The federal government has provided its support. Even Ontario Hydro has offered through a special economic diversification fund to provide another $10 million.
Supply
What is required is for the province to take its responsibility, not try to fob it off as to location to a board of governors, and move on. This project would provide some 500 direct jobs, another 500 indirect jobs and some several thousand students for that community which is desperate for jobs and for diversification because of the massive lay-offs which we suffered during the last two or three years.
I am sure those three or four points are very much in line with those of my hon. colleague across the way. It is essential, as we work our way through this recession, to find tools and take action to overcome the tremendous economic downturn that we face, the loss of jobs and the unemployment that so many thousands of Canadians face today.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Trade
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, first of all, I would like to thank the hon. member for Algoma. When he referred to Ontario Premier Bob Rae, this took me back to the First Ministers' Conference held last Monday. In fact I have nothing but praise for the Premier. He said at the conference that we should set politics aside and forget about being Conservatives, Liberals, New Democrats or whatever, and work together to develop Canada's economy.
That is what I as the member for Kamouraska-Ri-viere-du-Loup have been saying for the past eight years in my region and my riding. Politics does not do a thing for the economy. When opposition members in this House and in the provincial legislatures realize that politics is no way to help the economy, I guarantee we will create jobs. When we talk about programs, a government's program is like any other product. It has to be sold. I have been in the private sector for 28 years, and I know what I am talking about.
Earlier I referred to Bombardier in La Pocatiere. I held a press conference in November 1991 to announce a subsidy for Bombardier, but only the regional press showed up. We announced that 800 new jobs would be created in La Pocatiere over the next nine months. It was not mentioned in the national media or on CBC television because it was good news. They only want to announce bad news. When we realize that we have to start talking about the positive things that are happening,

February 14, 1992
Supply
it will be a big relief to realize that the federal government iscreating new jobs.

Madam Speaker, I would like to thank the member of the Liberal Party who moved this motion which calls on the House to condemn the government for its failure to take action to stop unemployment and to create additional employment in this country.
I was looking at an article recently in The Ottawa Citizen in which Judith Maxwell, a well-known Canadian economist, was trying to determine what were the reasons for the poor economic performance in Canada. She said: "Higher inflation and failure to invest in new technology are major reasons for the higher production costs in Canada, not social programs and wages".
It seems that the government has taken its focus at two issues, social programs and wages, so it is really missing the point of the problem, which is one of the reasons we are seeing such tremendous job loss in this country and why the government refuses to take effective action to increase employment in Canada.
In the same article Maxwell also blasted what she called the "very weak training effort by Canadian business compared with that by industry in the U.S., Japan, and Germany". I think that criticism can be directed not simply at business but also at governments in Canada, and in particular this government, because training is the key to a successful economy in the future and to successful participation in the future economy by those who need the training.
As you might know, Madam Speaker, one of the previous participants in this debate mentioned the announcement of a shutdown in Port Alberni within the last few days of two logging operations employing something like 340 men and 60 contractors. Over 400 people have lost their jobs in those two particular logging operations in my riding. As a person who comes from a community of 19,000 people that is largely dependent on the forest industry I can say that, in conjunction with a number of other lay-offs and permanent shutdowns that have taken place over the last several months and years, is causing tremendous economic problems.
I am not going to say that it is a dying community because Port Alberni where I come from has tremendous resilience. It has always been able to pull together and push back. It has been around for a long time. It has thrived for a long time. It has done well for a long time. Many times it showed the highest average income levels based on tax statistics of any community in the country, and it is going to do that again.
At this particular time things are looking pretty grim in Port Alberni. Between 1982 and 1984 we have seen 2,500 people lose their jobs in the logging industry at a time when there was no loss to the forest land base due to the environment or withdrawals from the working forest. It was simply an increase in speed of production, mechanization, changes in markets and that kind of thing. As a result those 2,500 people lost their jobs permanently in the forestry industry.
Just recently in that community we have seen a plywood mill shut down with the loss of roughly 300 and some jobs. We have seen a sawmill shut down, with another 150 to 200 jobs lost. We have seen processes within the pulp and paper mill in Port Alberni shut down. Again we are looking at something like 500 jobs possibly being removed from that plant and probably removed permanently. It is a community that is definitely suffering.
It is interesting, at the same time as the community is suffering, as those jobs have been lost and as MacMillan Bloedel, the major employer in the community, is declaring tremendous losses in its operations over the last year, that company has declared a 15 per cent dividend to its shareholders within the last week. Those shareholders are reaping the benefits that they do not deserve because that company is losing money. What is happening is that the shareholders are taking their dividends from the declining capital of that corporation. That is unfair to the community of Port Alberni. That is unfair to the workers in Port Alberni who are actually losing their jobs to pay those dividends to shareholders who have not done a lick of work, as far as I am concerned, in the forest industry.
In addition, MacMillan Bloedel has been investing in the United States. It recently invested in a $300 million oriented strand board plant down in Deerfield, Wisconsin. This was made more feasible as a result of the
February 14, 1992

changes that were brought about by the free trade agreement.
Recently the parallam process, a process for developing laminated beams that almost have the strength of steel and can be used as a substitute for steel beams, was developed in Canada by Canadian scientists. It has now been sent for manufacture down to the United States with partners in the United States. Again another $300 million investment. I suspect, in the last two or three years since the free trade agreement has allowed it that leeway, the company has now invested about $1 billion in the United States while it is shutting down its investments in British Columbia and putting workers out the door who have committed their lives, their skills and their talents to that company in Canada.
It is unfortunate we do not have companies operating in this country that have a sense of duty, responsibility, nationalism and patriotism for this country and a sense of responsibility for the workers.
Judith Maxwell was talking about the investment in training. A study was recently done by the Council of Forest Industries in British Columbia and by the International Woodworkers of America (Canada), the major union operating in the forest industry in that area, of 227 sawmill workers in a number of sawmills in British Columbia. The results of the study were as follows.
They found that 56 per cent of the workers had difficulty understanding training manuals at the grade 4 level. I am talking about the grade 4 level. Only 26 per cent of those sawmill workers were able to understand technical material relating to the operation of their equipment and to safety processes. Only 26 per cent was able to understand technical documents at the grade 12 level.
The fact is that when those people lose their jobs and they are literate at only the grade 4 level, we are talking about people who are unable to get jobs in the future. They simply do not have the skills, the education and the ability to get jobs in the future. Many of them, because they were trained on the machines they operated over the years, understood those machines very well. They understood the technical problems, the safety problems and were able to operate on those machines.
Supply
In fact, they were some of the best skilled workers in the world with respect to those machines. Once the machines became obsolete, the worker became obsolete as well. As Judith Maxwell said: "This is a country where companies expend very little". In fact, we are the lowest in the world in terms of the amount we invest in on-the-job education for our workers. As a result, we end up de-skilling those workers to the point where they end up not being suitable for employment in the future.
I was looking at an article just a few seconds ago from the National Anti-Poverty Association which talks about what the future hopes of those workers are, should they become unemployed, since they are literate at a very low level.
Let me quote from that document: "The National Anti-Poverty Organization, for example, estimates that low literate adults are twice as likely to be unemployed and many times more likely to need social assistance than other Canadians. Even if employed, such low literate Canadians earn only two-thirds of the average income of others".
Illiteracy is a tremendous impediment for Canadians to get jobs. In fact, the federal government, through the Department of the Secretary of State, has been warning Canadians that something like 38 per cent of all Canadians have difficulty reading material that they find on a day-to-day basis, whether newspapers, bus schedules, airline schedules or Hansard. All of these kind of things they have difficulty reading and understanding. The government has estimated that costs the people of Canada, the economy of Canada, something like $10 billion a year.
When we think of $10 billion a year and compare that to the deficit that this country is facing, we are talking about one-third of the national deficit that could possibly be attributed to the problem of literacy in this country.
We always look at Canada as a developed country. It is one of the leading countries in the world in terms of education. Yet, under this government, the educational level in Canada is actually going down and the illiteracy rate is actually going up. There is a sign here that we should be reading as parliamentarians and as members of government that we are doing the wrong thing with respect to training our work force.

February 14, 1992
Supply
Those sawmill workers, because of their low literacy levels, are not going to have the opportunity to get a job in the future. If that is the problem with those workers, it is certainly a problem with Canada. We should be spending a lot more time looking at the problem of education and how we can deliver education to our workers.
It seems strange that other countries do not have this problem, at least to the same rate that Canada does. I am thinking in particular of the nation of Sweden. I was recently looking at an Australian magazine called The Bulletin in which they were talking about the education systems in the various countries around the world.
It talks about the Swedish system which concentrates heavily on adult education and also on making education available to supplement their labour market strategy. It talks about leaving work in order to get involved in an education program in Sweden. They give an example of a millworker who left his job and went into an adult education program at the age of 52.
In Canada, we consider a 52-year old worker who loses his job to be no longer trainable. Yet, here is an example of a Swede who left his job at the age of 52 and went into a training program. The Government of Sweden pays him $12,600 for 28 weeks of training and $400 a week as a wage supplement while he is on that training program.
It has been estimated in Sweden that of those people who take those kinds of training programs, 70 per cent of them who leave at the conclusion of the program have a job within the space of six months. We do not have anything like that here in Canada; nothing like that in the province where I come from and nothing like that is offered by Employment and Immigration Canada.
I received this document in the mail from Employment and Immigration Canada. It cost $1.5 million to mail this document to every household in the country. It does absolutely nothing to improve the educational quality of the work force in Canada. In fact, it is virtually a waste of government money, but I think it is the only thing that the Minister of Employment and Immigration can really say that he has done in the last little while. Tens of thousands of Canadians are losing their jobs. Whenever
they go to him either through his unemployment insurance or through his training programs, there is almost nothing that can be done.
It is interesting that Sweden spends most of its unemployment money on the educational or training part of it and only a very, very small per cent on income supplement. In fact, to quote the article from the Australian magazine I was referring to, it says:
The country stints on cash benefits for the unemployed, doling out just .84 per cent of GNP for that purpose, but what they do is they pay people to go to training programs so that when they come out of those training programs, they will have the intelligence and the skills and the understanding to get into a job.
As I pointed out, it is usually within the space of six months that people who have taken those training programs end up re-employed in a permanent job.
There are other things that this government seems to neglect to do that could assist getting people into employment again or getting people into employment. I want to quote a document that was brought by Dr. Harris Jane from McMaster University to the special committee of the House on employment equity about the cost of discrimination, how that cost affects industry in Canada and the United States and how that costs society as a whole. Dr. Jane quoted a study, an economic report of the president in the U.S. on discrimination against blacks, Puerto Ricans, Spanish Americans, Indians and others, which shows that it can cost the U.S. economy a loss of up to $20 billion per year.
He also pointed out another author who indicated discrimination in the work place has decreased national income in that country by as much as 1.41 per cent or $9 billion annually.
We are now in the process of revising the employment equity legislation. We know what the tremendous cost is to people in this country when you discriminate against people based on colour of skin, the fact that they are a member of a visible minority, are aboriginal, are women, or are disabled. Those people in many cases have skills that are far higher than those who are actually hired to do the job. If we brought those people into the work force, they would be contributing far more, be far more productive and make our industries far more competitive.
February 14, 1992

We were told by Dr. Jane at that meeting that when President Reagan for ideological reasons offered to get rid of employment equity in the United States, those companies that had adopted employment equity policies which knew the advantage to their company and knew the advantage to the economy, insisted that President Reagan leave the program intact because it was helping America to be competitive and it was helping their industries to be competitive.
There are many things that we should be looking at in this country, examining our management practices, examining the way our industries are structured, examining how we handle social programs to make sure that we are getting the maximum benefit that we can possibly get. It is only when we improve those management practices, improve our industry, make sure investment is taking place, both by the people who are involved in industries as well as in the machinery and equipment they use, that we are going to get the most competitive economy we can possibly have.
The one thing we cannot do is constantly attack those social programs that the government seems to want to focus on. Things like medicare and transfer payments to the provinces which are used in education and social services are actually going to decrease productivity of our industry and of our work force and decrease the competitiveness of this country.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I listened with interest to the hon. member's speech, and like the hon. member I am aware of the difficult situation in the forestry sector in this country, especially in his province.
As you know, the forestry sector ranks among the five largest exporters in Canada and is responsible for a significant share of the $175 billion that we export. I think these industries are having trouble maintaining, let alone increasing their sales, as a result of increasing production prices and also because of certain environmental constraints as a result of legislation in a country that is our main customer, the United States.
The hon. member also mentioned the fact that equipment in the various plants was outdated. I would like to
Supply
ask a few technical questions. He referred to programs for retraining manpower and upgrading employee skills.
I agree, and I think my government's departments have already provided special programs to help the employees of these various companies.
However, when he talks about updating facilities, does he think keeping interest rates low is relevant and is this a policy our government should maintain? I think that when companies decide to buy, the cost of borrowing is an important factor. That is why in recent years, investment has gone down significantly in manufacturing. Now that interest rates are low, experts predict there will be a lot of new investment in 1992 and 1993.
I would like the hon. member to qualify his low interest rate policy, considering the need for companies to reinvest and to increase their technical capacity.
I would also like to ask him, considering that buying new equipment will create pressure on interest rates, how he would reconcile this with simultaneous pressure created by major highway and sewer projects favoured by his colleagues in the Ontario government and possibly by other provincial governments, and also by opposition members here in the House today. If there is too much pressure on demand, I think interest rates will go up, and this would make it more difficult to update the plants that provide work in his region.

Madam Speaker, I thank the member for his question. He talked a little about interest rates. I remind him that interest rates in Canada are really not much of a factor to multinational forest companies such as MacMillan Bloedel, the one I was referring to that operates in my constituency.
MacMillan Bloedel shows in its annual report that a great deal of its borrowings come from Japan where interest rates, especially over the past several years, have been far lower than they are here in Canada. They have also borrowed substantially in the United States. In Japan they were borrowing at rates that were 2 to 3 per cent. The United States rates were around 5 to 6 per cent at a time when rates in Canada were around 12 to 13 per cent. In the old days you could say that when the governments were borrowing money for infrastructure

February 14, 1992
Supply
programs and borrowing money from a limited domestic market or a North American market, there was a chance they could drive up the cost of money by taking a substantial amount of what was available in capital markets. Now the world is a capital market. You told us that we must understand that we are dealing with a global world. Now you must understand that we are dealing with a global world in terms of capital markets as well. A company like MacMillan Bloedel can borrow in Japan at 2 and 3 per cent and it can borrow in the U.S. at 5 and 6 per cent at the same time as money can be borrowed at 7, 8 and 9 per cent in Canada. Those companies do not recognize international boundaries in terms of capital markets.
Therefore, I do not think the fact that Canada's interest rates have come down has really been of much assistance to those companies. They have access to capital markets at lower rates elsewhere.
The problem with investing in Canada is that when these companies examine where to invest it is possible for them to ship natural resources in an unprocessed state to areas in the southeastern United States, across the border into the United States, which are closer to the market. There are lower labour costs there because of anti-union legislation such as right-to-work legislation in those states. That is what is driving investment out of Canada and into the United States.
The free trade agreement the government has developed for Canada has given companies far more freedom to take their investment across the border and put Canadian people out of work. That is one of the primary problems we are dealing with.
I hope I have dealt with most of the member's questions.

Madam Speaker, I was interested in the speech by the hon. member for Com-ox-Alberni because he is a member of the New Democratic Party. We in Ontario are faced with the problems created by the New Democratic government of Mr. Bob Rae.
We certainly were pleased to see his proposal in his fireside chat, that he was willing to contribute dollar for dollar to projects put forward by the federal government with the co-operation of both levels of government. As soon as I heard his speech I immediately wrote Mr. Rae a letter to point out that the federal government had
proposed to provide some $30 million for a new community college in Elliot Lake, Ontario, a community which has suffered the most massive unemployment of any community in northern Ontario, over 50 per cent and perhaps as high as 60 per cent.
I suggested to Mr. Rae that it would be really great if he would support that project from his side. Indeed the arguments were made to his party leader a couple of weeks ago when she visited Elliot Lake. I would hope that the hon. member would be able to support her view that the Ontario government should not procrastinate any longer, should make a decision to go ahead with that community college and should provide its share of the funding.
It not only has the responsibility to provide half of the funding along with the federal government but the responsibility to choose the location. However, it seems that the Government of Ontario has decided to establish a board of governors for the francophone community colleges for the whole of Ontario with the idea of letting the board choose the site.
It seems to me that the Government of Ontario has the responsibility to choose that site itself, and clearly Elliot Lake is the choice. The federal government is on board. Ontario Hydro has provided some $10 million through its working group. I would hope that the NDP Government of Ontario would not procrastinate and would make a decision to go ahead. That project would provide a lot of jobs. It would provide a student population in the community of some 2,000. It would be a great project for that community which has over 50 per cent unemployment right now.
I hope the hon. member will convey that message to the provincial premier.

Madam Speaker, of course I would not want to prevent the establishment of a worth-while project in Ontario. I am sure the member would not either.
The Government of Ontario has to operate through its legislation and procedures in the same way that every other government does. If he wants to change those procedures, I would suggest that perhaps the hon. member might run for office in the province of Ontario and hope he is more successful than his party was last time. If there is a proposal to improve the economy of Elliot Lake I will certainly get in touch with the Government of Ontario and lend my assistance to it.

Madam Speaker, I have read the motion tabled by my colleague from Toronto requesting that this House condemn the government for its refusal to take action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment in Canada. In October a 120-page report from a Harvard professor, Mr. Michael Porter, was published by request from the government and the Busines Council on National Issues.
I received a translation of that report and read it. It was veiy interesting. I also received from the Montreal office of the Canadian Manufacturers' Association a report it had prepared. It was sent by the president of the Quebec chapter.
These two documents contain valuable information and are quite similar even though the one from The manufacturers' association was prepared at least a year before that of Professor Porter from the United States. I would like to present some of the main points.
It is evident that the current problems of Canadian manufacturers which resulted in job loss are due to the high cost of the Canadian dollar. Everybody knows that, it has been said often enough.
Also mentioned in the reports are the interest rates which are much too high as compared to those of the United States. Sometimes the margin in Canada is 5.5 per cent higher than that of the United States. You can easily imagine how difficult it is for our small businesses to borrow at such high interest rates. Consequently there was a decline in the manufacturing sector which resulted in lost jobs. But we must not forget that perhaps the most important factor was the so-called free trade agreement. That agreement with the United States certainly had an effect. I do not need to elaborate. The news were far from encouraging when week after week we saw a great number of Canadian and Quebecer manufacturers that could not compete with American companies, and we know why when we look at the Canadian system.
We the Canadian people decided over the years to protect ourselves collectively with programs such as health care and old age pensions. I would like to note I am always surprised when I ask people whether they know that old age pensions do not exist in the United
Supply
States like in Canada. Most people seem surprised when I tell them that.
In Canada, we have put in place a pioneering system of social security for all the people. We are really a privileged people that the world envies. The free trade agreement cost us many jobs. We saw the results of that. To my great surprise, during 1988 until the end of the election, the Canadian Manufacturers' Association insisted that the deal was absolutely essential. It was its point of view just before the 1988 election and for some time after that. To my great surprise, in December 1991 the Canadian Manufacturers' Association decided to release a study. What did it say in its report? Simply that the free trade agreement was premature. Imagine, three years later it made up its mind. I told the Quebec president: "I am surprised to see that strong supporters of the deal as you were three years ago now realize that there were problems."
For three years they talked about a high dollar and high interest rates. Now they realize that the agreement was premature. He is saying today that we should have waited at least five years before signing that agreement. In other words, we should have stated our intention of entering into a free trade agreement, but we should have provided for a transition period which would have allowed us to adjust gradually, because a lot of adjustment was required. This was not done. We now see the results. This transition period of at least five years was necessary.
Second, what I find strange about the manufacturers association is when it says that the federal government should have known the Americans would be no less aggressive after the signing of the agreement. Imagine that. We kept repeating at the time of the signing of the agreement that the American government was not going to do anyone any favour. Why should it after the signing? We now see the kind of argument we get into with the Americans.
Finally, the manufacturers' association proposed a series of measures. Naturally it is still talking about an overvalued Canadian dollar and high interest rates. It says that our monetary and fiscal policies contribute to a reduction of personal savings, which leaves less money available for small and medium businesses. It also says

Supply
that we need initiatives to improve training and development. This is obvious.
Needless to say, the Japanese and the Germans are admired for their remarkable levels of education, especially when it comes to trades training. It is all over the news; you have probably read the same pieces I have. I wonder, why not copy them to a point? In the United States, they are facing the same problems as we are, but if we look to the East we can see what Germany and Japan are doing. In Japan at the present time 96 per cent of all its students graduate from high school. They all have basic knowledge or skills in mathematics, not super university degrees but at least basic skills required to deal with modern technology as it exists in the world today, and it is evolving fast. But here in America-because Canada and in the United States are in the same boat, a fine mess I dare say-only 70 per cent of our young people complete high school.
What is worse is that barely one per cent has the basic mathematical skills required to keep a job in high technology manufacturing industries. I repeat I am not talking about scholarly degrees in calculus or anything like that. I am only talking about the basic mathematical skills required to work in high technology industries. That gives you an idea. It was our doing. We have something to learn, not only from the Japanese and the Germans, but also from the Swedes and the Finns. In Finland in particular, and it has always amazed me, 20 years ago, its government told the pulp and paper industry: "Gentlemen, we have a new policy. From now on there will be no tree cutting unless you are at the leading edge of the pulp and paper technology". As you know, the Finns innovate a lot; they have equipment plants for the pulp and paper industry. But here, in Canada, even when we were the world's biggest pulp and paper producer per capita, we had no secondary industry producing equipment for the pulp and paper companies.
Unfortunately I do not have enough time to address this whole issue.
In conclusion, since the schools do not provide the necessary advanced training, I think the time has come for some kind of national service. Yes, a national service that has nothing to do with the military service. For at least two years, the young would attend classes and learn
a craft or get some technical training, which is a must today in the high technology industry in Canada.

Madam Speaker, I would like to start by thanking the hon. member for his speech. Could he perhaps explain his reference to a national service?

I am very much interested in his comments about a national service. Perhaps my friend and colleague can elaborate a little more on this concept.

Madam Speaker, this is not something I thought up, but I have been hearing more and more about this concept. People have been talking about it for years, and I remember I discussed it with colleagues in Quebec City, in the National Assembly, when we were astounded by the fact that at the present time 500,000 jobs are not filled because people do not have the technical skills, and I mean basic skills. I am not talking about university degrees.
There are 500,000 jobs that are not filled because we have not been able to train our young people through apprenticeship training and technical or trade schools. The national service concept is a very simple one. I do not know all the details, but I think we can skip those for the time being. The fact is young adults, as you know, have to go to school until they are 16. So starting at 16, 17, 18, 19 and up to 25 or 26, if they leave school and do not finish high school, of course they have no trade and so they are unemployed. Obviously they have no future.
My point is that we could do what they do in Germany, Sweden and Japan, and establish a national service, in co-operation with industry. Here in Canada, with the help of industry, we could train these young adults. They would have some discipline and a bit of order in their lives. It is not their fault but the important thing is they would have at least two years to learn a trade or some kind of technical skills in the industry. Industries know their own needs. There are 500,000 jobs waiting. They know their needs, and we could train these people. Training in those fields could be extraordinary.
February 14, 1992

Do you realize how helpful it would be for those young adults to to learn a trade or some basic technical knowledge for various industries? We could solve many problems in this way. Great challenges await Canada now. But if you want to face up great challenges, you must take big steps.
I say that a national service might be the answer for our young adults, because in the last few years we have almost had a lost generation in Canada. Our young people are not to blame. They did not get the required basic knowledge in school. We failed in that regard and we must recognize it.
But the time has come for important initiatives and I say that a national service, organized jointly with the industry, could be a giant step that would enable our young generation to fill existing jobs. It would also give them hope as well as a chance to contribute to Canada, to the welfare of all Canadians and, more important, to their own personal benefits, happiness and personal satisfaction.

Madam Speaker, the motion is that the House condemns the government for its refusal to take action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment in Canada.
This morning I asked the minister some questions about the level of unemployment in Canada and, as you heard, our rate is now among the highest in the OECD and G-7 countries. In looking at The Economist magazine for this week, the only countries with a worse unemployment rate than ours appear to be Australia, Italy and Spain.
It is a lot more than simple statistics which are not very meaningful to people. It is young people, students, older people, people 45 years of age who get lay-off notices. It is thousands of careers, families, children and grandparents and an awful lot of human beings. I am sure there are many people in your constituency as well, Madam Speaker, who are going around trying to find a job that does not seem to be there.
Supply
There are about 1.4 million Canadians looking for work today. If you consider the people who have stopped looking or who have stepped out of the work place, the number is considerably higher.
The Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre reported that Canada's unemployment rate would be almost 14 per cent if we included discouraged workers, those on temporary lay-offs, and took into account underemployment among those forced to work part time because of the shortage of full-time jobs.
Our employment rate is at one of the highest levels among the advanced industrial democracies. Among other things, the government has cut the Canadian Jobs Strategy by $100 million and raised the unemployment premiums for those with jobs and employers by 24 per cent. Reference was made this morning to a document from the employment and manpower department which mentioned how the government was going to make the $100 million in cuts in the budget and how the cuts would be allocated to particular regions.
A press released dated February 11 states: "Documents from CEIC reveal that the federal government is in the process of dismantling existing training programs across the country. At a time when the country is facing its worst economic crisis since the 1930s, the federal government proposes to respond to unemployment by slashing training dollars".
There is probably still more bad news to come. The government's own forecasts call for double digit unemployment late into 1992. A strong case can also be made that the government actually used prolonged high interest rates. I certainly concede that interest rates are very low now. In fact, our rates are among the lowest of the figures cited in The Economist this week. But they were too high for too long and it is a classic case of waiting until the horse is out of the bam before you close the door. Interest rates should have been lowered many months ago if we wanted to kick start the economy. Unfortunately it is going to take many months to have any positive results from our lower interest rates.
As I said, the case can be made that the government induced this recession in large measure with its high interest rates and high dollar to bring on a recession to lower the inflation rate in places like metropolitan

February 14, 1992
Supply
Toronto. Of course, metropolitan Toronto and southern Ontario have been hit as hard as any region by the made-in-Canada recession.
The Bank of Canada has lowered interest rates so much now that savings are in danger of leaving Canada, possibly causing a collapse in our dollar and renewed inflation. Low income Canadians are feeling additional pain because $411 million was cut from federal social housing programs.
According to the Canadian Association of Food Banks, the number of people receiving food assistance has risen 40 per cent over the last year. Our leader, the member for Beausejour, is thus quite correct in calling for the redirection of $25 million from Ottawa's advertising budget to Canada's 1,300 food banks. Imagine, 1,300 food banks in this country.
Our provincial economic growth was weakened last year by poor markets-I am talking about Alberta now, forgive me-for oil and gas and by high dollar and interest rates that together choked our natural resource sectors.
The entire petroleum industry has been shrinking and restructuring in an attempt to survive. Staff cuts are likely to continue. Petro-Canada, for example, plans to close about 1,200 service stations across the country and that is likely to be only the first wave of another wave of cuts.
There were six years of relative prosperity. I give the government credit for some of that. I think there is no doubt that for a period its policies were working. I would remind members opposite that during those six years we had 34 separate tax increases and the deficit is still not far off the figure of 1984 when the government took office.
The federal debt, as most people know, is virtually out of control. The government has squandered the opportunities available through the mid to late 1980s to bring spending under control.
Sustained economic success for Canada can only be achieved by tough-minded fiscal and monetary policies such as those pursued by countries like West Germany since 1948. How are we going to kick-start an economy which is now in a recession?
Low interest rates and a lower dollar will probably require at least six months to generate significant new
economic activity. In the meantime, our party, the Official Opposition, has proposed among other things, first, allowing first time home buyers to make down payments of 5 per cent for the purchase price of a CMHC approved mortgage instead of the current minimum of 10 per cent. I salute the government for accepting that proposal. We think and hope that it might create as many as 50,000 jobs in the home building industry and cost the taxpayer nothing.
Second, our party has proposed that first-time home buyers be permitted the use of $7,500 tax-free from their RRSPs.
Third, we proposed an immediate federal infusion of $1 billion with equal investments by provincial and municipal levels of governments to fix roads, sewers, bridges and other parts of Canada's aging municipal infrastructure.
Finally, we propose using $150 million for basic training for the unemployed, even to the point of not lowering the deficit by as much as planned next year.
Madam Speaker, you have been sitting there listening to one person after another get up and fulminate against the government. You are probably quite tired of listening to it all day. However, as you know from your constituents, there are an awful lot of our fellow citizens who do not need to be out of work. If we had a little flexibility, a little willingness, a little determination by the Minister of Finance and those around him, we could turn this recession around.
In closing, I urge the government to do some of the things we have suggested and what other people have suggested as quickly as it can for the good of the 27 million people who live in this country.

There will be a five-minute question and comment period.
Before I give the floor to the hon. member for Welland, I would like to ask the hon. member for Edmonton Southeast not to presume the reason why I may or may not be tired.
Mr. Gilbert Parent (Welland -St. Catharines-Tho-rold: Madam Speaker, you are probably tired for the same reason all of us are. It is the end of the week and that is the only explanation for it.
February 14, 1992

I thank my colleague from Edmonton Southeast. I was in his riding about six months ago and I had occasion to talk about the conditions there at the time.
He mentioned in his speech today the fact, for example, that in Edmonton, his city, and also in my city of Welland, we have food banks. There are 1,300 food banks across the country.
One would think that in a country as rich as we are and, yes, as caring as we are-Canadians are caring people-that we as members of the House of Commons could somehow urge this government to see that surely one of the rights that Canadians should have is the right to at least have food.
I will talk about the employment situation. In the last week or so I visited the Port Weller dry docks in my riding and they went from a peak of 1,100 people at one time building ships for our country. They are now down to 250 people and they have work, they tell me, to carry them through only until the end of April.
They are hoping they will get one of our defence ships, the Prolecteur, in there. I hope they do too. The fact is that most of the 250 people remaining are going to be unemployed until that time.
The hon. member also mentioned the car industry. We have over 10,000 workers in the Niagara peninsula who work not only for General Motors but for the parts industries. I think that as these people are affected, they affect not only their immediate communities but also the province and the whole nation.
We have unemployment of about 16 per cent. Some of the things that the hon. member has mentioned to us are common sense things. Surely the government will have a look and see that its right wing, Attila the Hun tactics are not the answers for what we are going through right now.
As one of the members on the other side has said, if we are in a "severe recession", I would think that what they are trying to do is push us into a depression. I would hope that they would listen to the common sense of the member who has just spoken.
One of the questions that I would like to ask the member, and he touched on it very briefly, is about the

oil patch. In Edmonton and Calgary and in Alberta generally, we have most of the people who work in the oil industry and now we see this morning the cutbacks at Hibernia.
What incentives or what encouragement could the government give to these people who in some ways generate a great many jobs to not only produce better but to produce more efficiently? Then we as Canadians could all benefit from their expertise and their contribution to the country. I am talking about the people in the oil patch and the oil industry, and I know he is very familiar with that.

Madam Speaker, I have a neighbour who lives in southeast Edmonton who recently told me that he works one month off and one month on in the oil patch, but not the oil patch in Canada. He works in North Yemen. He gets on a plane at the beginning of every second month and flies to wherever you get off the plane for North Yemen and works there for one month, and then comes home to see his family in southeast Edmonton.
Why does he and others who do a similar thing, have to go to the Middle East to look for oil when, as the member may not know, we still have lots of oil and gas left to find in Alberta? I understand we have in Alberta, for example in the tar sands, twice as much oil as they have in all of the Middle East. Why are we not developing that secure quantity of product for this country and for this continent, for that matter?
I do not have any answers for him on that. I think the answer is that our expertise is needed in Canada and I would like to see more of it used in Canada to find oil and gas in Canada so that people like my neighbour do not have to leave his young family every second month to go off and live in a tent somewhere in North Yemen.

Madam Speaker, it is indeed a pleasure to take part in the debate today.
Although we do not have a lot of time left, I just want to remind the listening public what we are debating. The motion was put forward by the member for York South- Weston. It reads:
That this House condemn the government for its refusal to take
action to alleviate the intolerably high levels of unemployment in
Canada.

February 14, 1992

We do not disagree with the urgency of the matter of high unemployment. The debate, in the last few moments especially, has been very reflective and I also use the words instructive and possibly constructive.
It makes no difference on what side of this House you sit, if you are a compassionate human being and a Canadian you have to be concerned that 1.5 million people are unemployed in this country. It is of great concern.
I would just like to pick up on some of the themes I have heard here today, in particular in the last speech. It is interesting to note, as the member from Edmonton pointed out, that statistics do not tell it all. I refer to the fact that it is predicted that Canada will lead the OECD countries in growth of the economy. That sounds good. That 3 per cent figure or 3.5 per cent or more, whatever it happens to be, is one which I think we can all lean on and take some satisfaction from.
However, the difficulty is that our society, our economy, is going through such stressful changes that despite the fact that we may lead the western world in economic growth next year there may not be any resulting change in the unemployment figure. Companies are finding new ways to do business and are becoming much more efficient at how they conduct that business. There are many examples even in my own riding in the last year of that happening.
The pulp and paper industry has been under siege in recent years in this country. In my own riding some of those companies have reduced their labour force dramatically while at the same time, in that same period, their productivity has grown. Although the output of the company has grown, the number of employees actually being employed has decreased. That is a recurring theme in the Canadian economy and in the world economy. We are finding better and more efficient ways of doing things. However, at the end of the day there is obviously a human cost to that efficiency. That is very disturbing.
I think that all of us on both sides of this House find no comfort at all in those numbers, in those figures.
One of the things that we have done in this country in the last number of years is allow our debt and deficit position to get out of hand. As a result of allowing that to happen this very day in this country of ours, 35 cents out of every tax dollar Canadians send to Ottawa is spent servicing the debt, paying interest or providing the
interest payment on the debt we have incurred over the last number of years in this country. That means we only have 65 cents with which to do something because the other 35 cents that is paying interest on the debt is not productive money.
The difficulty is that it hamstrings the government's ability to get out of situations we now find ourselves in. If we are talking about an injection of more moneys into the economy to get the economy moving, none of us are opposed to that, none of us on either side of this House.
The difficulty the government finds itself in now is that if we do inject some more money into the Canadian economy it will be borrowed money. That figure of 35 per cent will grow higher and higher so we have to find new ways and possibly more imaginative ways to get the economy going.
One aspect we have overlooked in this country in recent years is the training of our workers. We have done a very poor job in this country, a very poor job. As a government we have to continue to put more moneys into education and the training and retraining of our workers.
For example, in Japan most corporations dedicate about four weeks out of the year to individual worker training. None of our major corporations in this country come even close to that number. Apparently in the banking community there are a number of banks in Canada that are starting to do that, but they are only doing it in terms of one week. Madam Speaker, you can imagine if you look at the auto sector, the pulp and paper industry, our computer industries, and the telecommunications industry in this country what we could achieve if we had the foresight a few years ago to designate training for our workers with the help of government.
That is what I think we have to do. Where we can be successful is to get that interchange between governments and business working the way it does in some other countries of the world. The country that I point to is Japan, that little economic miracle, if you wish. We have it within our ability to do it and we must do it.
That is one of the ways I think we can solve some of the problems that are staring us in the face today without just simply shoving money at them, pouring money into them. That is not going to solve anything at the end of the day, nothing at all.

I want to quote Michael Wilson. He sums up his interpretation of what has happened in this country in the last 100 years. Michael Wilson is a friend of the hon. member for York South-Weston.
Mr. Wilson said, and I think most of us would agree with this: "In this country of ours, Canada, for the first 100 years we lived off of our resources. In the last 25 years we lived off of our credit".
It does not work that way any more. We have to find a better way to do it. I believe that by working together we can achieve better and bigger things in this country.
